Trial_Design.evidence: Fifty patients selected for increased risk of left ventricular dysfunction after cardiac surgery and randomized to temporary biventricular pacing or standard of care (no pacing)

Participants.evidence: Fifty patients selected for increased risk of left ventricular dysfunction after cardiac surgery

Intervention.evidence: randomized to temporary biventricular pacing or standard of care (no pacing)

Objective.evidence: Objective: Vasoactive medications improve hemodynamics after cardiac surgery but are associated with high metabolic and arrhythmic burdens.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Vasoactive agents were assessed after cardiopulmonary bypass, after sternal closure, and 0–7 hours after admission to the intensive care unit.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: randomized to temporary biventricular pacing or standard of care (no pacing)

Number_Randomised.evidence: Fifty patients selected for increased risk of left ventricular dysfunction after cardiac surgery and randomized

Result_Outcome.evidence: mean vasoactive-inotropic score decreased in the biventricular pacing group from 12.0±1.5 to 10.5±2.0 and increased in the standard of care group from 12.5±1.9 to 15.5±2.9.
